Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Does NEAT always lead to higher fitness value?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=eQWaiJvPjoRApccM9lpqYodGmyjDOnR-42cxZ-Zem039mxepiZAD
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

I recognize it is a broad statement, but after doing research on this
subject for a few years it is what I have concluded. I am currently working
on a manuscript now that greatly bolsters the argument, but it is not out
yet. I will let you know when it is.

Nevertheless, I started all of this with the great hope that evolution could
do a great job of picking its own parameters. I would love to be proven
wrong! Please let me know if you have any success. I have found that
evolution consistently does  poor job of evolving its own settings.

Here is a challenge: take Ken's default settings for a good NEAT run.
Compare those to a situation where a GA picks those settings. I'll bet ya a
six pack o porter the hand picked values do significantly better.



Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
517.214.1060

> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Does NEAT always lead to higher fitness value?
> 
> 
> On Nov 7, 2007, at 6:44 AM, Jeff Clune wrote:
> 
>> Beware: evolution is very bad at choosing good settings for evolution.
>> That's in addition to all of the extra computation time.
> 
> 
> This is a rather broad statement, and, paper or not, I don't buy it.
> I believe a Differential Evolution would work *very* well to choose
> NEAT parameters.
> 
> I've thought of doing this very thing myself.  Like the OP, I find the
> hand-tuning of the numerous NEAT parameters inelegant and painful.
> --
> Stephen Waits
> steve@...
> http://swaits.com/
